Congratulations to NANOGrav for detecting evidence that gravitational waves fill the cosmos. 

These ripples in the fabric of space happen when massive objects like black holes circle one another before colliding. The result brings us closer to understanding how galaxies evolve.… Show more
What are gravitational waves? We dove into this topic in an episode of our Curious Universe podcast (transcript included):

Is NASA mining asteroids? No, but we love studying them. 

The science gained from asteroid missions—like our upcoming #PsycheMission to a unique metal-rich world—could one day benefit future cosmic resource endeavors. http://nasa.gov/asteroids

Come explore asteroids with us!

Take a guided tour of our “Eyes on Asteroids” visualization app today at 11am PT (2pm ET). Our guide and an asteroid expert will show you how to explore ~28,000 near-Earth objects and talk about the ways we study them. http://bit.ly/asteroids-live

Every December, the Geminids light up the night sky in one of the biggest meteor showers of the year.

As our Parker Solar Probe swoops around the Sun—closer than any spacecraft in history—it's helping uncover how these shooting stars came into existence: https://go.nasa.gov/3NfS0se
Steve Bowen, 10-time spacewalker.

Enceladus, Saturn's icy moon, is known for its geysers that erupt with water from a subsurface ocean. 

Scientists have just detected phosphorus—an uncommon element that's a key building block for life—in the plumes that these geysers spray: https://go.nasa.gov/43FVtY1

U.S. and international media: You are invited to @NASAKennedy to interview subject matter experts and view the @NASA_Orion spacecraft slated for the next three #Artemis missions.

"I try to be visible, to show folks who may still be in the closet that one can live their authentic life and be a part of something so amazing." Celebrate #Pride and read the story of Amy Lendian, a systems engineering supervisor at @NASAKennedy. https://go.nasa.gov/3NfJcCU

Today's spacewalk is scheduled to start around 8:55am ET (1255 UTC) and run for six hours.

The ocean is one of Earth’s largest ecosystems and helps moderate our climate. NASA has an array of missions dedicated to studying this precious part of the planet, with more to come. 

Dive in: http://go.nasa.gov/43yYj0w
It’s giving…life.    #WorldOceansDay

Large amounts of smoke have been pouring into the eastern U.S. from fires in Quebec. The wildfire smoke is degrading the quality of surface-level air that tens of millions of people breathe.

Several NASA satellites are collecting data on the plumes: https://go.nasa.gov/3p1pPFk

Join us for a Twitter Space! We’re celebrating 50 years of studying gamma-ray bursts, spurts of bright light coming from some of the largest explosions in the universe. Hear from experts about gamma-ray astronomy & the high-energy events that create them.

How do we know what Earth's climate was like long ago? If you look closely, there are clues just about everywhere across our globe. Some are easy to see and others are more subtle. 
@NASAClimate
 scientist Dr. Gavin Schmidt explains.

Want even more?: http://go.nasa.gov/3NihKpm

Today's #CRS28 cargo launch is being waved off due to high winds in the recovery area. 

Monday's launch attempt is scheduled for 11:47am ET (1547 UTC), with NASA TV coverage beginning at 11:15am ET (1515 UTC).
